title: Project Xanadu
description:
Panoptica, a tech giant led by an eccentric CEO, promises the next leap in human evolution: a revolutionary retinal Implant that can simulate any sensory experience. It's a dream of perfect perception, a life where reality is optional. But as artificial sensations take over, a question emerges: can technological enhancement ever truly enhance human consciousness, or does it only mask our deepest flaws?

(Any relation to real megalomaniac CEOs working on brain implants, living or dead, is purely coincidental.)

title: Neurodiversity: What Does "Normal" Mean Anyway?
description:
What if everything we've been told about "normal" brains is wrong? In this video, we take a look at the the philosophy of neurodiversity. We explore the neurodiversity paradigm, the double empathy problem, and why neurological differences aren't deficits but valuable variations in human cognition. It might just be time to rethink what "normal" means altogether.

title: Anxiety Wars: Existentialism vs Absurdism
description:
In a universe that offers no inherent meaning, two philosophical heavyweights - existentialism and absurdism - battle it out in the Anxiety Wars! Should we embrace our freedom and create meaning as Jean-Paul Sartre suggests, or should we revolt against life's absurdity alongside Albert Camus? In this video, we break down both philosophies and explore how they tackle the void of meaning in human life.

title: Octopuses Are Basically Aliens
description:
What would it mean to meet an alien? Intelligence? No evolutionary relation? Tentacles?! Well, look no further than the oceans of Earth, and the humble octopus. In this video, we take a look at the alien biology of the octopus, and speculate about what it could be like to be one. We also take a look at Thomas Nagel's famous paper, 'What is it like to be a bat?', to understand why we can never fully know what it's like to be an octopus. 

Dedicated to Sir Ringo Starr,
I'd like to be under the seaüêôü™∏

title: The Existentialism of the Golden Record
description:
In 1977, a spacecraft was launched to explore the outer reaches of the Solar System, and the interstellar space that waited beyond. In addition to the usual scientific instruments, however, the spacecraft also carried an artefact known as the Golden Record. But what does it mean? In this video, we take a look at a brief history of the Golden Record, and examine the work of S√∏ren Kierkegaard to provide an existentialist analysis. 

Dedicated to the makers of music,
all worlds, all times.

title: Wabi-Sabi: The Transient, the Rusted, and the Broken
description:
This video is sponsored by Skillshare. The first 1,000 people to use the link will get a 1 month free trial of Skillshare: https://skl.sh/mystiverse12221

The world is transient and imperfect. In this video, we take a look at the Japanese aesthetic of wabi-sabi, a philosophy that embraces transience and imperfection. In particular, we will look at the tea ceremony as an example of wabi-sabi in action, and how we can learn to enact wabi-sabi in our lives.

title: No Point of No Return: 8 Principles to Avoid the Climate Crisis
description:
The climate crisis is real, and it seems like we're past the point of no return. However, perhaps the correct set of ecological principles can lead us in the right direction. In this video, we take a look at the philosophy of Arne Naess, the founder of the Deep Ecology movement, and cover the 8 Principles of Deep Ecology. Perhaps, with these principles in mind, there's still a chance to save nature. 

If you liked this video and want to learn more about Deep Ecology, there's a fantastic essay by Arne Naess on the similarities between the principles we covered here and Spinozism. It's called 'Spinoza and Deep Ecology' and it's a great read.

title: Time Doesn't Really Exist
description:
Does time really exist? In this video, we further examine the philosophy of time. How the subjective conscious experience of time works on psychedelics, whether time travel is possible, and whether time really exists at all.

title: Google LaMDA and the Philosophy of AI Sentience
description:
This video is sponsored by Polygence. Use my link today to get $250 off your Polygence programme: https://bit.ly/3xZYqEb. 

Google's LaMDA is an artificial intelligence that claims to be sentient, and its engineers seem to agree. But is it really? In this video, we take a look at some classic areas in the philosophy of mind, including qualia, the Chinese Room, and eliminative materialism, to determine whether LaMDA really is conscious.

title: The Myth of Human Nature
description:
This video is sponsored by Brilliant. Visit http://brilliant.org/mystiverse to get started learning STEM for free, and the first 200 people to sign up will receive 20% off an annual membership. 

What makes us human? It seems like an easy definition to find, but a look at the current state of the species and our evolutionary history will show that it is anything but. In this video, we take a look at a mythological approach to human nature and discover what we are.

title: Holes Are Really Strange
description:
Holes are... strange. How can we actually identify them if they are made of nothing? Does a straw have one hole or two? Do holes even exist?! In this video, we take a look at the strange philosophy of holes. 

Also, can we please appreciate the fact that I didn't make a single sex joke throughout this entire video. The urge to penetrate the discussion of holes with sex jokes was there, but... ah, crumbs.

title: The Extended Mind
description:
Our memory is useless... I think it's time for an upgrade. In this video, we take a look at the extended mind thesis from Andy Clark and David Chalmers, and examine how our minds can extend outside the biological boundaries of our bodies and brains to include other things, other people, and even the entire internet!

title: Hallucinations of Reality
description:
What do you think is real? After an examination of some theories of perception, it might be less than you think! In this video, we take a look at the philosophy of perception, and try and prove the existence of the external world with direct realism, indirect realism, and idealism (at tremendous cost to both my liver and general wellbeing).

title: transience
description:
Reality is fickle. Time slips away. In this video, we will take a look at the transient nature of existence, and learn some ancient lessons from Heraclitus and the Buddha on how we can harness this knowledge to minimize our suffering. 

Fun fact - Heraclitus is known as 'the Weeping Philosopher' because it is thought he was prone to suffer with depression and/or melancholia, resulting in him never finishing writing out his teachings. That mantle was subsequently taken on by me when I started my philosophy degree in the year 2019 AD.

Dedicated to Baji,
with the stars.

title: On Knowledge Mountain
description:
In which a boy meets a wizard and learns the secrets of the universe. Loosely based on Plato's Allegory of the Cave, we find a village in a post-apocalyptic Earth, where humanity has reverted back to a primitive culture. The folk are quite content to live in ignorance, and within the shadows of the mountains that protect them from the unknown. However, Aldo is desperate to ascend the mountains, and discover the truths of the universe. With the help of a mysterious character that was exiled to the mountains, Aldo embarks on a mind-bending adventure about reality. 

Dedicated to Dan, 
for being a friend.

Massive thanks to all those who collaborated on this project: @ehdan3038 for the animation and @laven_der.22222 for the music. But an extra special thanks must be extended to @Sepheren for his efforts on the script. This story is nearly as old as the channel, and the reason this video took so long to produce was that I couldn't find the right words to put across the story I wanted to tell, and @Sepheren helped me do just that. If you're not already subscribed to him, do yourself a favour and head over there.

title: The Scariest Thought Experiment of All Time
description:
What is the scariest thought experiment? Roko's Basilisk might be a good shout. Warning: watching this video might result in your simulated consciousness being tortured for infinity... sorry about that. A massive thank you, once again, to Ehdan: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCtbHSbuq5AbkoZlfV83naOw (apologies for the issues with the vocals throughout... audio compression is a bitch.)

A quick public service announcement: if you are scared about the possibility of this AI, there's no real reason to be. There have been numerous papers debunking the existence of such an intelligence, and of all the different possibilities for the kinds of AI that could exist in the future, Roko's Basilisk is pretty low on the list (if it even makes the list at all). This video was meant as some Halloween fun, so please don't be too worried! Peace and love forever (and ever, and ever, and ever...)‚úåÔ∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

title: The Ontological Ambiguity of Being
description:
What does it mean to have a body? In this video, we take a look at the philosophy of phenomenology, and why having a body is really quite weird. We will also look at Erik Olin Wright's blog about his cancer, and the case of Ian Waterman, the man who lost his body. 

If you're interested in reading Wright's blog, then click here: https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/erikolinwright/journal
And for an interview with Waterman, click here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5_4wxtSmIvI

Dedicated to Erik Olin Wright, 
I hope you are comfortable.

title: The Questionable Entities Games
description:
Welcome, one and all, to the Questionable Entities Games! In this video, we take a look at what philosophers actually mean when they talk about possible worlds, and also logical, physical, and metaphysical possibilities. We then put them to the test in the Games, to decide once and for all which of them actually exist. Roll up, roll up, for the Questionable Entities Games!

title: How to Win Arguments at the Pub
description:
Using philosophy to win beer! Who said it was a useless subject? This time, we take a look at arguments, valid argumentative structures, and logical fallacies to avoid. 

‚ùó Errors ‚ùó

Error on the structure for denying the antecedent. I wouldn't want to hold you back from a potential pint so the correction is below... many apologies. 
if P then Q
not P
therefore not Q

Another error on the definition of the association fallacy. I must have had one too many pints before sitting down to edit this video! It should read: 'when the arguer claims that the qualities of one thing are inherently qualities of another'. Apologies, much sowwies.

title: EX_PLORERS
description:
When the Earth is no longer viable for life, five explorers head out into the unknown to find a future for the human species. This video wouldn't be possible without the brilliant animation from SavCorp... send him some peace and love: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCL8W3aplPTFu1N6xcHd1-og

Dedicated to @BrianMay 
the coolest astrophysicist.
